qas.question: When was the successful test of the 3.6-inch HAA gun?
When did the 3.7-inch HAA gun become preferred?
What gun did the Royal Navy start using?

answers.text: 4.5-inch (114 mm) gun in a twin turret

qas.question: How long of a running time did the Number 199 fuse have?

context: Britain had successful tested a new HAA gun, 3.6-inch, in <a0_0>1918<a0_0/>. In <a1_0>1928<a1_0/> 3.7-inch became the preferred solution, but it took 6 years to gain funding. Production of the QF 3.7-inch (94 mm) began in 1937; this gun was used both on mobile carriages with the field army and transportable guns on fixed mountings for static positions. At the same time the Royal Navy adopted a new <a2_0>4.5-inch (114 mm) gun in a twin turret<a2_0/>, which the army adopted in simplified single-gun mountings for static positions, mostly around ports where naval ammunition was available. However, the performance of both 3.7 and 4.5-in guns was limited by their standard fuse No 199, with a <a3_0>30-second running time<a3_0/>, although a new mechanical time fuse giving 43 seconds was nearing readiness. In 1939 a <a4_0>Machine Fuse Setter<a4_0/> was introduced to eliminate manual fuse setting.
